intro: Moquilea imbaimadaiensis, commonly known as the Andean quillay, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes. It belongs to the family Ericaceae and is characterized by its evergreen shrub form with dense, leathery leaves. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink, typically blooming in the spring. It thrives in cool, moist climates and is often found in cloud forests and mountainous areas. Due to its ecological importance and ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens in temperate regions.
